item.title: AI/ML Readings (living doc)
item.description: This is a (living) list of AI/ML Blogs that I visit. Personal Blogs Andrej Karpathy, also his blog at stanford. Company Blogs Google Research TasteHit - Full of intuitions and the big picture. Forums Reddit Machine Learning - Remain upto date with what’s happening in Machine Learning Reddit Artificial Intelligence - Same for AI

item.title: Analysing AlphaGo
item.description: (I wrote this piece as part of an assignment for Udacity’s AI Nanodegree program) Introduction ‘Go’ is typically an adversarial search problem where the objective is to find the best move for the AI Agent to defeat it’s opponent, given a board position. Go is a two player, turn taking, deterministic game of perfect information. Two main factors make Go very complex to solve: Go has an average branching factor ‘b’ of ~250 options per node (chess ~35) Go has an average depth ‘d’ of ~150 moves (chess ~80) These factos make the state space of Go (bd) enormous to search end to end using traditional techniques.

item.title: Visualising AI Search Algorithms
item.description: Search algorithms help find the correct sequence of actions in a search space, to reach a goal state. The sequence of actions might be: Sequence in which cities are to be visited to travel from a source to a destination under a given cost function (shortest path, cheapest fare etc.) Sequence in which an agent should play moves in a game (chess, tic tac toe, pacman etc.) to win a board game Sequence in which a robot arm should solder components on a PCB under a given cost function (e.
